bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, August 6, 1951

div1.p: Hench is discouraged by the Cuban government's lack of response to the Camp Lazear memorial. The government will not permit Hench to donate money to the site because it is a Cuban national monument, but the government has not allocated any money itself.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas, August 6, 1951
div1.opener:
August 6, 1951
Senorita Maria Teresa Rojas
Quinta San Jose
Calle Real
Quemados de Marianao
Havana, Cuba
My dear Senorita Rojas:
div1.p:
Thank you so much for your letter of July 22, just received. I am distressed
that I did not receive your other letters and the clippings. These never
reached me and I would so much like to have seen them. There seems to be
some difficulty with mail between Cuba and the United States in recent months.
After hearing of Johnny Moran's death, I sent Mrs. Moran a letter. It was re-
turned to me two or three times marked, “Address unknown.” I later found that
she was still living at the same house, sent it again and it was delivered
after a period of two or three months.

I have gotten rather discouraged at the reaction of the Cuban Government toward
my proposition to help memorialize Camp Lazear. You may remember that on my
last visit I became very hopeful. I saw many officials, including the Vice-
President, who assured me that the Cuban government would set aside money to
memorialize Camp Lazear. Because the caseta had been named a national monument
they would not let me spend some of my own money to protect it. Politely but
firmly I requested the Vice-President to let me at least erect around the caseta
a galvanized iron protection so that while the government is going ahead with
their plans the caseta would be protected, but he insisted that the Cuban
government would not let me do even that - that they would do it. Later Mr.
Moran sent me a clipping saying that the government had appropriated $50,000
for the site. Then that administration went out of office and nothing happened.
Some time later Mr. Moran sent me a clipping which distressed me greatly. Another
administration had renamed the caseta a national monument, but not to Loazear
but to Finlay. The write-up erroneously (and I suspect deliberately) stated that
it was in this caseta that Finlay had done his work. Even so, the administra-
tion did not set aside any money, not even a starter.

I feel, therefore, quite stymied. They won't let me spend my own money because
it is a national monument and they won't spend any themselves, they won't even
protect the building, and when they talk of it they talk of the Finlay caseta.
When I write my book the matter should be clarified but by then it may be too
late. I had hoped to have some American help but the Americans will not help
if the Cuban government does not participate and particularly if the Cubans do
not recognize the Camp for what it is - the cite where the ingenious theory
of Finlay was proven to be correct by the work of Reed and his colleagues in
a camp named for the martyr Lazear.

Although greatly discouraged, I have not given up. I hope to go to Cuba
in January for a medical meeting and if I can summon enough enthusiasm to
start all over again, I will try to see the appriate people. Last time I had
even drawn up tentative plans for the memorial which I submitted to
various officials for their comments and suggestions. They liked them
but that was the end of that.

If you have any way of getting the clippings that you mention (the one Johnny
Moran sent me was a small photograph with a very short paragraph) or if you
know of any way you can help me or know whom I can see, I shall be very glad
for your help.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
